# Content Structure: rpa-curriculum-lesson-maps

## Curriculum Overview

This document contains a sequentially structured curriculum with modules (M0-M20) and lessons (L001-L999).

---


<!-- File: RPA-01-fundamentals-and-value‚Äîlesson-map.md -->

Complexity Legend

[F] Foundational ‚Äî Basic concepts, prerequisites

[I] Intermediate ‚Äî Practical application, integration of concepts

[A] Advanced ‚Äî Complex problem-solving, experience-dependent

[E] Expert ‚Äî Specialized knowledge, architectural decisions

# M0: RPA Fundamentals & Value ‚Äî Lesson Map
## Core Concepts & Landscape

## L001: What is RPA? Attended vs Unattended vs Hybrid [F]
## L002: RPA vs BPM vs iPaaS vs Scripts: Boundaries & Fit [F]
## L003: Bot Types: UI Bots, API Bots, Document Bots [F]
## L004: Platform Overview: UiPath, Automation Anywhere, Power Automate [F]
## L005: Capability Map: Discovery‚ÜíBuild‚ÜíRun‚ÜíMeasure‚ÜíImprove [I]
## L006: Business Value: Cost, Quality, Speed, Compliance [F]
## L007: When NOT to use RPA: Anti-Patterns & Risks [I]
## L008: RPA in Enterprise Programs & Digital Transformation [I]

## Foundations for New Builders

## L009: Recording vs Hand-Crafted Flows: When to Use Which [F]
## L010: Variables, Arguments, Data Tables, Collections [F]
## L011: Orchestrators/Control Rooms Basics [F]
## L012: Environment Setup, Credentials, and Vaults [F]
## L013: Reusability: Libraries, Snippets, Components [I]
## L014: Exception Surfaces: Business vs System Exceptions [I]
## L015: Logging & Trace IDs for Bot Runs [I]
## L016: Minimum Viable Governance for Small Teams [I]

## Operating Models & Personas

## L017: Roles: BA, RPA Developer, Solution Architect, COE Lead [F]
## L018: Engagement Model: Discovery‚ÜíDesign‚ÜíBuild‚ÜíUAT‚ÜíHypercare [F]
## L019: Citizen Development vs Pro Dev: Guardrails [I]
## L020: COE Charter: Standards, Templates, Reviews [I]
## L021: Intake & Prioritization with Value Scoring [I]
## L022: Stakeholders: IT, Security, Compliance, Audit [I]
## L023: Funding & Unit Economics (Bot-Hours, AHT, FTE Saves) [A]
## L024: Roadmapping: Crawl‚ÜíWalk‚ÜíRun for RPA [I]

# M1: Process Discovery, Mining & Assessment ‚Äî Lesson Map
## Discovery Techniques

## L001: Workshops, Shadowing, SIPOC, and BPMN Lite [F]
## L002: Process/Task Mining Tools: Concepts & Signals [I]
## L003: User Telemetry & Desktop Capture (Ethics & Consent) [I]
## L004: As-Is Documentation & Happy Path vs Edge Paths [F]
## L005: Waste & Variation Analysis (Lean/Six Sigma) [I]
## L006: Candidate Repository & DOR/DOD for RPA [I]
## L007: Feasibility Triage (Apps, Citrix, Mainframe, Web) [I]
## L008: Legal/Privacy Considerations in Discovery [A]

## Assessment & Scoring

## L009: Automation Potential Score (Volume, Rules, Stability) [F]
## L010: Complexity Score (Systems, Selectors, Exceptions) [I]
## L011: Benefit Model: Time Saved, Quality, Compliance [I]
## L012: Risk Model: Control Points, PII, SoD, Audit [I]
## L013: SLA/SLO Mapping & Seasonality [I]
## L014: Tech Constraints (Citrix, Legacy UI, MFA) [I]
## L015: Build vs Buy vs Refactor with APIs [A]
## L016: Business Case & Prioritization Matrix [I]

## Target State & Hand-off

## L017: To-Be Process with BPMN and Wireflows [I]
## L018: RACI/Stakeholder Map for Build & Run [I]
## L019: Data Contract & Source-of-Truth Mapping [I]
## L020: Control Points & Evidence Collection Plan [A]
## L021: Non-Functional Requirements (Latency, Throughput) [I]
## L022: Success Metrics & Acceptance Criteria [I]
## L023: Pilot Selection & Rollout Strategy [I]
## L024: Handover Package to Developers/Architects [I]

# M2: Design Standards & Patterns ‚Äî Lesson Map
## Solution Design

## L001: Layered Design: Orchestration, Business Logic, UI/API Adapters [I]
## L002: Stateless vs Stateful Bots & Checkpointing [A]
## L003: Idempotency & Re-Entrancy for Safe Re-Runs [A]
## L004: Config-Driven Bots & Feature Flags [A]
## L005: Transaction Unit Design & Commit/Rollback [A]
## L006: Secure Secrets & Connection Abstractions [I]
## L007: Telemetry First: Correlation IDs & Context [I]
## L008: Documentation: PDD, SDD, and ADRs [I]

## Patterns

## L009: Retry with Backoff & Jitter [I]
## L010: Bulk vs Streaming Workloads [I]

## L012: Work Queues & Priority Scheduling [I]
## L013: Circuit Breakers & Fallbacks (Manual Ops) [A]
## L014: Anti-Fragile Selectors & Anchors [A]
## L015: Headless/API-first where possible [I]
## L016: Golden Path Templates & Reusable Snippets [I]

## Anti-Patterns

## L017: Pixel-Based Clicks without Anchors [F]
## L018: Overloaded Monolith Bots Doing Everything [I]
## L019: Secrets in Code/Config Files [F]
## L020: No Timeouts/Guards for Waits [F]
## L021: Hardcoded Paths & Magic Numbers [F]
## L022: Swallowing Exceptions without Evidence [I]
## L023: No Negative Tests/Golden Inputs [I]
## L024: No Rollback/Compensation Strategy [A]

---

You are generating a polished, publication-ready lesson for a Robotic Process Automation (RPA) Curriculum.
Read and internalize these two inputs before writing anything:

1. LESSON_GENERATION_PROMPT_GENERIC.md ‚Äî this defines the canonical 10-section structure.
2. content_structure_rpa-curriculum-lesson-maps.md ‚Äî this defines where the lesson fits in the broader curriculum.

---

### LESSON METADATA
- Lesson Code: M0-L001
- Lesson Title: What is RPA? Attended vs Unattended vs Hybrid
- Module: M0 ‚Äî RPA Fundamentals & Value
- Subtopic / Focus Area: General
- Complexity Level: F (Foundation)
- Estimated Duration: 45 minutes
- Target Audience: RPA developers, process automation engineers, and business analysts
- Organization Context: Organizations implementing Robotic Process Automation

**Prerequisites & Context**
- Prior Knowledge Required: Basic understanding of the domain
- Related Lessons: Related lessons in the same module
- Domain Context: Robotic Process Automation, business process automation, digital transformation

---

### INSTRUCTIONS

You must generate a **complete, polished lesson** following the exact 10-section structure of the template.
Each section must be written in clean, engaging, professional prose using proper Markdown syntax.

**Length & Depth Guidelines**
- [F] Foundation: ~350‚Äì400 lines, 2‚Äì3 core concepts, 3 scenarios  
- [I] Intermediate: ~400‚Äì500 lines, 3‚Äì4 core concepts, 4 scenarios  
- [A] Advanced: 500+ lines, 4+ concepts, multiple scenarios  

**Content & Technical Requirements**
1. Include working code examples (‚â•15 lines each) demonstrating realistic RPA automation patterns.  
   Languages accepted: RPA platform-specific languages (UiPath XAML, Automation Anywhere AAL), Python, VB.NET, C#, or YAML (for configuration).  
2. Use real metrics and trade-offs (e.g., ‚Äúreduces provisioning time by 60%‚Äù, ‚Äúsaves $50K annually‚Äù).  
3. Anchor explanations in RPA-specific terminology: attended bots, unattended bots, orchestrators, process mining, exception handling, and bot governance.  
4. Connect code and architecture examples to common RPA platforms ‚Äî UiPath, Automation Anywhere, Power Automate, Blue Prism, and open-source alternatives.  
5. Discuss business impact, not just technology. Every technical concept must map to a measurable outcome (cost, velocity, reliability, compliance).  
6. Avoid filler phrases (‚Äúlearn about‚Äù, ‚Äúunderstand‚Äù); use precise, action-oriented verbs.  
7. Each code example must include a short contextual explanation and expected outcome.  
8. Every section should open with 1‚Äì2 framing sentences that orient the learner before details or lists.  
9. Use active voice, short sentences (under 25 words), and clear transitions.  
10. Maintain tone balance: professional, instructive, and confident ‚Äî not academic or conversational.  

---

### FORMATTING & STYLE GUIDELINES

- **Headings:** Use `##` for major sections, `###` for subsections. Capitalize key words.  
- **Bullets:** Use `-` for list items. Avoid numbered lists unless order matters.  
- **Code Blocks:** Use fenced code blocks with language tags (` ```ts`, ` ```sql`, etc.) and concise comments.  
- **Tables:** Use clean Markdown tables with short headers; follow with 1‚Äì2 lines of interpretation guidance.  
- **Callouts:** Use icons like ‚úÖ, ‚ö†Ô∏è, üí° for emphasis when appropriate.  
- **Spacing:** Insert blank lines before and after headings, code blocks, and tables for readability.  
- **Tone & Flow:** Alternate between explanation and application. Every theoretical statement should lead into an example or outcome.  
- **Lexical Clarity:** When using technical terms (e.g., ‚Äúbot isolation‚Äù), add a short clarifier in parentheses on first use.  

---

### QUALITY GUARANTEES

Your final output must:
- Contain all 10 sections from the template in order.  
- Have consistent structure, formatting, and flow.  
- Read naturally, as if authored by an experienced SaaS educator.  
- Contain no meta-text, instructions, or placeholders.  
- Begin immediately with `# Lesson M0-L001: What is RPA? Attended vs Unattended vs Hybrid` or the first section heading.  

Do **not** include:
- Any ‚ÄúLLM Prompt‚Äù or template boilerplate.  
- Any context or metadata explanation.  
- Any quality assurance notes at the end.

---

### FINAL OUTPUT

Deliver the **final, learner-facing Markdown lesson**, cleanly formatted and publication-ready.

- **Callouts:** Use icons like ‚úÖ, ‚ö†Ô∏è, üí° for emphasis when appropriate.  
- **Spacing:** Insert blank lines before and after headings, code blocks, and tables for readability.  
- **Tone & Flow:** Alternate between explanation and application. Every theoretical statement should lead into an example or outcome.  
- **Lexical Clarity:** When using technical terms (e.g., ‚Äúbot isolation‚Äù), add a short clarifier in parentheses on first use.
